content:
This came to my attention while working on the proof that Alexandrov discrete spaces are locally path-connected. (#26492)
In Mathlib, the intersection of all neighborhoods of a set s in a topological space is currently called exterior. However, for most mathematicians, the exterior of a set s refers to the complement of its closure (see here).
This naming is very misleading, so exterior is clearly in need of renaming.
@Yaël Dillies, do you have any suggestions for a better name?
(docs#exterior)
No, I had and still have no better name. This operation seems to never be given a name in the literature, so I chose exterior to emphasize the similarity with interior.
All I can think of now is something like minimalNhd, infinitesimalThickening, both of which sadly don't look like interior at all
I asked ChatGPT, and it suggested the name nhdsCore. What do you think?
Not much better (my suggestion is nhdsKer or nhdsKernel)
Do we really have to emphasize the relationship with interior? It seems to me that it's only similar in the special case of an Alexandrov space.
environ, environment, surrounding, ambient, context, entourant
As for my own opinion (not ChatGPT’s), if we don’t need to preserve a connection with interior, then I think supNhds would be a great name that directly reflects the definition.
Why sup?
yeah shouldn't it be inf
I made a mistake, sorry!
I wanted nhdsKer since it's (nhdsSet s).ker
Also if we're working with sets then usually it's union instead of sup
I guess this time it's a sUnion

Since I confused supNhds with infNhds, accepting your suggestion would lead to something like interNhds or sInterNhds. But in either case, it gives the impression that the result is itself a neighborhood, which is misleading. So in the end, I’m leaning toward nhdsKer.
Notice that if s = {x} is a singleton, exterior s is the set of points that docs#Specializes to x. With this viewpoint maybe you can say exterior s is the "generalization" of s.
I think I like this viewpoint
I think that the descriptive name nhdsKer is still the best option in this case (although every option is better than exterior).

After some thought, I’ve come to the conclusion that exterior should ultimately be renamed to cointerior. I’d love to hear what others think.

Option 1: “neighborhoods kernel” (nhdsKer)
:cross_mark: The term kernel is used across many areas of mathematics, and without explicitly specifying that this is the kernel of a filter, the meaning is unclear.

Option 2: “kernel of neighborhoods filter” (nhdsKer)
:cross_mark: Too long.

Option 3: “generalizations” (generalizations)
:cross_mark: Similar to Option 1, the term generalization is used in many contexts in mathematics and can be confusing.

Option 4: “cointerior” (cointerior)
:check: Avoids confusion with existing concepts, emphasizes the relationship with interior as @Yaël Dillies originally intended, and—as seen in docs#gc_exterior_interior—these operations form a Galois connection in Alexandrov spaces. This parallels the naming pattern in docs#gc_coinduced_induced.
you listed nhdsKer twice?

Their def name is the same, but what we call it in the context of informal mathematics differs.
In short, the problem with nhdsKer is that it’s hard to give it an appropriate name in the context of informal mathematics.
i'm not sure i agree with your argument against option 1; nhds gives a filter, it plausibly refers to a kernel of filters, and i can't imagine how it could refer to a different kind of kernel...

Edward van de Meent said:

i'm not sure i agree with your argument against option 1; nhds gives a filter, it plausibly refers to a kernel of filters, and i can't imagine how it could refer to a different kind of kernel...

The important points are the following two:

  1. In informal mathematics outside of Mathlib, it's not very common to think of neighborhoods as filters.
  2. The concept of the kernel of a filter is quite a specialized mathematical notion.
Sure, people don’t usually think in terms of filters in the real world. But we are talking about Mathlib here. Anybody meeting this notion in Mathlib will be familiar with filters by that point.

Based on everyone's feedback, it seems that "neighborhoods kernel" (nhdsKer) is well-received, so I’m planning to open a renaming PR to replace exterior with this new name.
Thank you all for your input!
Done! #26918
